content: We publish images to Docker's official image program, but they are currently not explicitly licensed. There's a PR to add in the standard Apache/MIT dual setup, but I'm a bit squeemish on just YOLO merging it: https://github.com/rust-lang/docker-rust/pull/74. Does this seem like a thing we can just do? Do we have to track down all of the previous contributors (there are only 5 including me, so that shouldn't be too hard hopefully)?
It would certainly be appropriate to ping previous contributors and have them leave a comment, give them a minimum week or two to reply.
Sure, but I am more concerned with "legally sufficient" than "a nice heads up".
It'd also be good to confirm that MIT/Apache is the appropriate license choice, since Dockerfiles aren't really code in the traditional sense.

Well if there's only 5 of you and you all sign off on the license change then that's certainly sufficient.
The only large-scale open source relicensing that I'm aware of having the process written down about is when Dolphin did it: https://dolphin-emu.org/blog/2015/05/25/relicensing-dolphin/
@Steven Fackler That licensing is appropriate for the Dockerfile.

@Steven Fackler For the overall Docker image, you probably need to document that Rust is under MIT/Apache-2.0, dependencies of Rust are under various permissive licenses (with a pointer to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/COPYRIGHT , as incomplete as it is), and the base image you use is under various licenses (with a pointer to whatever base distribution you're using).
